name: Desmarest's Hutia
description: It has a stocky body, square head, and relatively short legs with slender toes and sharp claws, useful for climbing trees. Its base color is brown, with a rusty tint on the back.
proportions: Body length 30–50 cm; tail length 15–30 cm; weight 4–7 kg
attractions: The hutia may look somewhat clumsy at first glance, but it climbs trees adeptly. Like all rodents, it has continuously growing incisors for nibbling leaves or shoots, supplementing its diet with small animals. A relatively gentle creature, it has suffered due to its tasty meat. Once abundant on Cuba and nearby islands, it is now much rarer. A group of hutias (also known as Cuban hutias) can be found in the so-called America area, next to the ocelot enclosure. They breed regularly here, and watching the playful young is undoubtedly a memorable experience.
breeding: We have kept them since 1963. The first animals came directly from Havana.
